title: 109_s4069
content: The Act titled "Deceptive Practices and Voter Intimidation Prevention Act of 2006" aims to address deceptive practices in elections. The Act "Deceptive Practices and Voter Intimidation Prevention Act of 2006" prohibits knowingly deceiving others about election details such as time, place, and manner of conducting elections for various offices. The Act prohibits deceptive practices related to voter eligibility, candidate party affiliation, and communication endorsing or opposing candidates in elections. It also allows for a private right of action under certain circumstances. The Act prohibits deceptive practices related to voter eligibility, candidate party affiliation, and communication endorsing or opposing candidates in elections. Subsection (c) of section 2004 of the Revised Statutes is amended to allow any person aggrieved by a violation of subsection (b)(2) to institute a civil action for preventive relief in a United States district court. The Revised Statutes (42 U.S.C. 1971(e) and (g)) are amended to update subsection references. Section 594 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include criminal penalties for intimidation and deceptive acts in communications. It is illegal to deceive someone about election details or candidate affiliations to prevent them from voting. This includes misrepresenting the source of any communication related to elections. Any public communication promoting, supporting, attacking, or opposing a clearly identified candidate in specific elections is prohibited. Violators of this rule will face penalties. Any violation of the prohibition on public communication promoting or attacking a candidate in specific elections may result in a fine of up to $100,000, imprisonment for up to 1 year, or both. These penalties will take effect upon the enactment of this Act. SEC. 3. REPORTING FALSE ELECTION INFORMATION. Any person can report deceptive acts related to election details such as time, place, voter eligibility, candidate affiliation, and communication origin to the Assistant Attorney General of the Civil Rights Division of the Department of Justice. The Election Campaign Act of 1971 prohibits deceptive acts that promote, support, attack, or oppose a candidate in a federal election. The Assistant Attorney General must investigate reports of deception within 48 hours and take corrective action, including providing correct information to affected voters and referring the matter for criminal prosecution. The Attorney General is required to investigate reports of deception within 72 hours before an election and take corrective actions, including providing accurate information to affected voters. Regulations will be developed in consultation with the Election Assistance Commission. The Attorney General, in consultation with various organizations, will conduct a study on providing corrective information through public broadcasts within 180 days. The Attorney General will submit a report to Congress within 180 days detailing the results of a study on corrective information. Additionally, within 90 days after any federal election, a report compiling allegations of deceptive practices will be submitted to Congress. Each report will include detailed information on specific allegations. The report to Congress will include detailed information on specific allegations of deceptive tactics, corrective actions taken, effectiveness of those actions, any lawsuits filed, statistical compilations of allegations, geographic locations affected, populations impacted, and status of investigations. The Attorney General must report on specific allegations of deceptive tactics, including the status of investigations. The report will be made public and includes information on Federal offices. Appropriations are authorized for the Attorney General to carry out this section.
